JOB DESCRIPTION:
We are a fast-paced startup (Series B). We need an HRBP to support our Product & Engineering org (150 people).

Responsibilities:
- Coach managers on performance reviews and conflict resolution.
- Drive employee engagement and culture initiatives.
- Handle employee relations issues with empathy.
- Partner with leadership on org design.

Requirements:
- 5+ years in HR, preferably in Tech.
- Strong knowledge of employment law (compliance).
- High EQ and ability to build trust with engineers.
resume:
RESUME:
Barbara Smith
Senior HR Manager | 15 Years Experience

Experience:
- HR Manager at Legacy Bank (2010-Present)
  - Managed compliance for 500+ branch employees.
  - Reduced legal risk by implementing strict attendance policies.
  - Conducted 100+ investigations into policy violations.

Skills: Compliance, FLSA, FMLA, Employee Handbooks, Investigations.
transcript:
INTERVIEW TRANSCRIPT (Duration: 40 mins)

Interviewer: Hi Barbara. Coming from a bank to a tech startup is a big change. Why the switch?

Candidate: I want to bring some order to the chaos. I hear startups are messy. I'm good at writing policies and making sure people follow the rules.

Interviewer: Interesting. Let's tackle a scenario. A high-performing Senior Engineer, Dave, has started coming in at 11 AM and leaving at 7 PM. He's delivering all his code, but his manager is annoyed because the daily standup is at 10 AM. Dave says he works better late at night. What do you do?

Candidate: Well, the policy is 9-to-5, right? If the standup is at 10, he is late. That is time theft. I would issue a verbal warning immediately. If he does it again, I'd move to a written warning. We can't have people making their own schedules. It sets a bad precedent.

Interviewer: But he is our top performer. If we write him up, he might quit. Is there a middle ground?

Candidate: If he quits, he wasn't a team player. Rules are rules. If you let the "stars" break the rules, you open the company up to discrimination lawsuits from the other employees who *do* show up on time. Compliance has to be black and white.

Interviewer: I see. How do you handle "Performance Improvement Plans" (PIPs)?

Candidate: A PIP is essentially the first step of termination. I make sure the manager documents every single mistake for 30 days. We need a paper trail so they can't sue us for wrongful termination. It's about protecting the company assets.

Interviewer: Do you ever see a PIP as a tool to actually help the employee improve?

Candidate: In my 15 years, I've never seen anyone survive a PIP. It's usually better to just cut them loose and save the paperwork, but legal requires the process.

Interviewer: Okay. We do quarterly engagement surveys. If the "Manager Effectiveness" score drops in the Engineering team, how would you investigate?

Candidate: I would look at who complained. Are they the low performers? Usually, people complain when they are being held accountable. I'd audit the time-sheets of the complainers to see if they are actually working.
